source.b6de62dc:
'''
SF: Good!
- does inches need to be an int?
- nice string output!
- Would add just one or two comments before the code (even just
describing what the program does in general)
'''

inches = int(input('Enter amount of inches '))
feet = inches//12
remaining_inches = inches%12
print(f'{inches} inches is {feet} feet {remaining_inches} inches')
#Not much to comment here, just did what was asked

source.cef7dbcd: This section is for coding :) Suggested 60 min.
source.dabf23eb:
Requirement Description Points Earned
Originality All code is your own. Any code snippets that are not your own are properly cited. No more than 5 lines from any website. 10 points 10
Planning & Reflection The "make a plan" section includes a detailed description of how you plan to complete the project. Reflection is thoughtful and answers all required questions. 10 points 10
Compiles Code Compiles 10 points 10
Comments Code is properly commented 10 points 5
Conventions Naming and style conventions are approriate 10 points 10
User Input Program asks for a number of inches 10 points 10
Calculation Program successfully calculates inches and feet 30 points 30
Print Results are printed as in the example 10 points 10
source.6e6176c8:
Here, write a 1 paragraph reflection answering the following questions:

*   What was the hardest part of this project?
*   What was the easiesy part of this project?
*   How did you utilize your peer feedback?
* What was different between your plan and the final project?
* How well did you plan? Was your idea too easy? Too hard? Just right?
* If you had unlimited time, what would you add to this project?
source.28d5b734:
You will be creating a unit converter. Your finished program should have output like this:

```
How many inches? 45
45 inches is 3 feet and 8 inches
```

Your task:
1.   Ask the user for a number of inches (it will be an integer)
2.  Convert the number of inches into feet and inches, as above

Want to make it better? You could...
* fix the grammar if there is only one inch
*   Allow users to enter decimals
*   Allow users to choose different measurements (45 inches is how many meters?)
*   Anything else you can think of!
source.a23a76f0:
In this space, write what you plan to do to complete this project. Keep in mind that you will be given approximatley 2 hours of class time to work on this project. Suggested 10 min.

```
#You may choose to plan using pseudocode. You could put that here.

```
I'm gonna need an input for inches, then I need to divide that input by 12 and carry over the remaining. Something like-
```
inch = input('enter amnt of inch')
foot = inch//12
print(inch, ' inches is ', feet, 'feet')
```
source.ea71c442: Hardest part for some reason was trying to figure out/understand the '%' function. The easiest part was the input and print statements. I didn't have any peer feedback. I threw my plan together quickly so there were a lot of problems. For one, I didn't use int, I also didn't incorporate the '%' function. I planned as well as I could've with my understanding at the time. Except for forgetting int, that wasn't very good. I think that my idea was simple enough. It could have been expanded upon, but I think that it's fine as it is. I would've added more units to convert to and I would have maybe used a conditional statement asking what the user wanted to convert from inches. I would have also fixed the grammar, maybe using conditional statements or something. Reason I didn't do any of this even though I could've is because as you probably know already I am in quarantine and feeling like garbage.
